docs.title: Welcome to GEE Assistant
docs.text: GEE Assistant simplifies your Google Earth Engine (GEE) workflows in Python. Whether you are a beginner looking to learn GEE fundamentals or an expert needing quick utility functions, this package is designed for you.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Quick Init: Handle authentication and initialization in one go.
  • Spectral Indices: Calculate NDVI, NDWI, EVI, and more with simple function calls.
  • Cloud Masking: Ready-to-use cloud masking functions for Landsat and Sentinel.
  • Export Helpers: Streamlined export functions for Images and Tables.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
import geeassistant as gea

# Initialize
gea.init()

# Check it works
print(gea.get_info(ee.Number(5)))

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.7 or higher
  • A Google Earth Engine account
  • Optional (for advanced plotting):
  • R installation (v4.0+)
  • R packages: ggplot2, tmap, ggspatial, sf, dplyr

docs.title: Install via pip
docs.text:
You can install geeassistant directly from PyPI (once published):

pip install geeassistant

docs.title: Install from Source
docs.text:
To install the latest development version from GitHub:

git clone https://github.com/pulakeshpradhan/geeassistant.git
cd geeassistant
pip install .

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
To verify that the package is installed correctly, open a Python shell and run:

import geeassistant
print(geeassistant.__version__)

docs.title: Initialization
docs.text:
Before using GEE functionalities, you must initialize the library. geeassistant handles the standard ee.Initialize() call and can trigger authentication if needed.

import geeassistant as gea

# Simple init
gea.init()

# Init with a specific project
gea.init(project='my-gee-project')

docs.title: Calculating Indices
docs.text: One of the most common tasks in remote sensing is calculating spectral indices.

docs.title: NDVI
docs.text:
Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) is used to quantify vegetation greenness.

import ee
import geeassistant as gea

# Load a Landsat 8 image
image = ee.Image('LANDSAT/LC08/C01/T1_TOA/LC08_044034_20140318')

# Calculate NDVI (B5 is NIR, B4 is Red for Landsat 8)
ndvi_image = gea.indices.calculate_ndvi(image, nir_band='B5', red_band='B4')

# The resulting image has a new band named 'NDVI'
print(ndvi_image.bandNames().getInfo())

docs.title: NDWI
docs.text:
Normalized Difference Water Index (NDWI) is useful for water body mapping.

# Calculate NDWI (B3 is Green, B5 is NIR for Landsat 8)
ndwi_image = gea.indices.calculate_ndwi(image, green_band='B3', nir_band='B5')

docs.title: Cloud Masking
docs.text:
geeassistant provides helpers to mask clouds.

# Function to mask clouds for Landsat 8
masked_image = gea.utils.mask_clouds_landsat8(image)

docs.title: Exporting Data
docs.text:
Exporting images to Google Drive is simplified.

# Define a region of interest
geometry = ee.Geometry.Rectangle([77, 12, 78, 13])

# Export
gea.utils.export_image_to_drive(
    image=ndvi_image.select('NDVI'),
    description='ndvi_export_example',
    folder='GEE_Exports',
    region=geometry,
    scale=30
)

docs.text: ::: geeassistant.core handler: python options: members: - init - get_info

docs.title: Graphics Module
docs.text:
The graphics module provides high-level wrappers around R's powerful plotting libraries (ggplot2, tmap) to create publication-quality maps directly from Python.

Requirement

This module requires R to be installed on your system. It also requires the rpy2 Python package, which is installed automatically with geeassistant. The R packages ggplot2, tmap, ggspatial, sf, and dplyr must be installed in your R environment.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
import geeassistant as gea
import geopandas as gpd

# 1. Check if R environment is ready
ready, msg = gea.graphics.check_r_environment()
if not ready:
    print(msg)
    # gea.graphics.install_r_packages() # Run this once if needed

# 2. Prepare Data (e.g., from a Shapefile or GEE export)
gdf = gpd.read_file('path/to/my_data.shp')

# 3. Create a static map with ggplot2
gea.graphics.ggplot_map(
    data=gdf,
    title="Vegetation Index Map",
    output_file="ndvi_map.png"
)

# 4. Create a thematic map with tmap
gea.graphics.tmap_map(
    data=gdf,
    title="Reference Map",
    output_file="ref_map.png"
)
